content:
The nLab taught me:

An (n,r)(n,r)(n,r)-category is a higher category such that, essentially:
- all kkk-morphisms for k>nk>nk>n are trivial.
- all kkk-morphisms for k>rk>rk>r are reversible.

I want to convert this into a precise definition using the model of quasicategories.

  • What is a kkk-morphism?
  • When is a kkk-morphism trivial? (Guess: if it is equivalent to an identity kkk-morphism. But that just provokes the questions "what is an identity kkk-morphism?" and "when are two kkk-morphisms equivalent?", which I am not able to answer myself.)
  • When is a kkk-morphism reversible?
I think you should try these exercises yourself!

But one thing I just told you is that in a quasicategory all kkk-morphisms are reversible for k>1k > 1k>1. So quasicategories are not going to help you understand the difference between reversible and nonreversible 2-morphisms, 3-morphisms, etc.
You can, however, figure out why in a quasicategory all kkk-morphisms are reversible for k>1k > 1k>1.

John Baez said:

But one thing I just told you is that in a quasicategory all kkk-morphisms are reversible for k>1k > 1k>1.

I read this all the time. But bizarrely nobody says what kkk-morphisms are and what "reversible" means. I have the feeling category theory is a very beginner unfriendly subject, and people hide ideas and definitions.

I can do that exercise, but how can I ever check my solution?

Just tell me.

You say that category theory is a beginner unfriendly subject. That might be true, but you're not doing category theory. You are now starting to do (∞,1)(\infty,1)(∞,1)-category theory. This cutting-edge math, not for beginners. If you don't know category theory and 2-category theory reasonably well, it's going to be hard.

But if you read this:

  • John Baez, An introduction to n-categories, 1997.

you'll see I talk about 2-morphisms in the simplicial approach. I say what they are, and I show how to reverse one, and why.

I can do that exercise, but how can I ever check my solution?

In math you check things by seeing if they cohere: by seeing if they make sense in light of everything you know. Also, you talk to people about them.

John Baez said:

But if you read this:

  • John Baez, An introduction to n-categories, 1997.

you'll see I talk about 2-morphisms in the simplicial approach. I say what they are, and I show how to reverse one, and why.

Great read! (I finally took the time to read most of it.)
Thanks!

John Baez said:

I think you should try these exercises yourself!

Before talking about general nnn-morphisms, here is a guess for how 3-morphisms could be defined:

Let AAA and BBB be objects, and f,g ⁣:A→Bf, g\colon A\to Bf,g:A→B 1-morphisms. I use the convention that a 2-morphism α ⁣:f→g\alpha\colon f\to gα:f→g is a 2-simplex α\alphaα such that

  • d0α=idBd_0\alpha = \mathrm{id}_Bd0​α=idB​ (idB\mathrm{id}_BidB​ is s0Bs_0Bs0​B),
  • d1α=gd_1\alpha = gd1​α=g, and
  • d2α=fd_2\alpha = fd2​α=f
    -- see (1) in the picture.

Now let α,β ⁣:f→g\alpha, \beta\colon f\to gα,β:f→g be two 2-morphisms. We want to define what a "3-morphism from α\alphaα to β\betaβ" is. I propose the following: a 3-morphism Γ ⁣:α→β\Gamma\colon \alpha \to \betaΓ:α→β is a 3-simplex Γ\GammaΓ such that

  • d0Γ=s0idBd_0 \Gamma = s_0\mathrm{id_B}d0​Γ=s0​idB​ (which is the same as s1idBs_1 \mathrm{id}_Bs1​idB​ by the way),
  • d1Γ=s1gd_1\Gamma=s_1 gd1​Γ=s1​g,
  • d2Γ=βd_2\Gamma=\betad2​Γ=β, and
  • d3Γ=αd_3\Gamma=\alphad3​Γ=α
    -- see (2) in the picture.

picture.jpg

But I have problems when it comes to defining the identity 3-morphism idα ⁣:α→α\mathrm{id}_\alpha\colon\alpha\to \alphaidα​:α→α. I had the idea to define idα:=s2α\mathrm{id}_\alpha:=s_2\alphaidα​:=s2​α. But then the simplicial identities imply:

  • d0idα=s1gd_0 \mathrm{id}_\alpha = s_1 gd0​idα​=s1​g,
  • d1idα=s1fd_1 \mathrm{id}_\alpha = s_1 fd1​idα​=s1​f,
  • d2idα=αd_2 \mathrm{id}_\alpha = \alphad2​idα​=α,
  • d3idα=αd_3 \mathrm{id}_\alpha = \alphad3​idα​=α.

The last two equations make sense (they are compatible with the definition of "3-morphism from α\alphaα to α\alphaα" I gave above). But the first two don't. Can one fix that somehow?

(By the way, here's a conceptual question: In a quasicategory composition is defined as a relation and not as an operation. That is, two 1-morphisms f ⁣:A→Bf\colon A\to Bf:A→B and g ⁣:B→Cg\colon B\to Cg:B→C don't have a specified composite g∘f ⁣:A→Cg\circ f\colon A\to Cg∘f:A→C. Instead, there is a relation of the form "a 1-morphism h ⁣:A→Ch\colon A\to Ch:A→C is a composite of fff and ggg". This makes sense because such a composite hhh is uniquely determined up to homotopy -- and we only care about a 1-morphism up to homotopy anyway. But why, then, is there a specified identity idA:=s0A\mathrm{id}_A:= s_0AidA​:=s0​A instead of a relation of the form "f ⁣:A→Af\colon A \to Af:A→A is a identity of AAA"?)

Leopold Schlicht said:

  • d0idα=s1gd_0 \mathrm{id}_\alpha = s_1 gd0​idα​=s1​g,
  • d1idα=s1fd_1 \mathrm{id}_\alpha = s_1 fd1​idα​=s1​f,

I think everything looks right except that these two should be

  • d0(s2α)=s1(d0α)=s1idBd_0 (s_2 \alpha) = s_1 (d_0 \alpha) = s_1 \mathrm{id}_Bd0​(s2​α)=s1​(d0​α)=s1​idB​ (=s0idB = s_0 \mathrm{id}_B=s0​idB​),
  • d1(s2α)=s1(d1α)=s1gd_1 (s_2 \alpha) = s_1 (d_1 \alpha) = s_1 gd1​(s2​α)=s1​(d1​α)=s1​g.

Ah, right, thanks! I now see why I did that wrong: for 1-simplices σ\sigmaσ I am used to thinking that d0σd_0\sigmad0​σ is the codomain of σ\sigmaσ and d1σd_1\sigmad1​σ is the domain of σ\sigmaσ. I shouldn't do that with 2-simplices. :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
The next step would be to define composition of 3-morphisms. Probably composition of 3-morphisms is witnessed by 4-simplices. But how do you visualize these? (I can't draw 4-dimensional things.)
At some point one has to stop drawing things. But it's not hard to draw a 4-simplex.
And you can use this picture to figure out the famous "pentagon identity" for the associators when you're composing four 1-morphisms in a row in a bicategory.

@John Baez I don't like this way of drawing 4-simplices, because I want to write down the name of each nnn-simplex for n=2,3n=2,3n=2,3 in its interior, but in that picture this gets very messy.

Then let's forget about pictures. I want to inductively define what an nnn-morphism between two (n−1)(n-1)(n−1)-morphisms is.

Recall:

The identity 1-morphism idA\mathrm{id_A}idA​ is defined to be s0As_0As0​A.
I already said that a 2-morphism from fff to ggg (where f,g ⁣:A→Bf,g\colon A\to Bf,g:A→B) is a 2-simplex α\alphaα such that

  • d0α=idBd_0\alpha=\mathrm{id}_Bd0​α=idB​,
  • d1α=gd_1\alpha=gd1​α=g,
  • d2α=fd_2\alpha=fd2​α=f.

Furthermore: the identity 2-morphism idf\mathrm{id_f}idf​ is defined to be s1fs_1fs1​f.
A 3-morphism from α\alphaα to β\betaβ (where α,β ⁣:f→g\alpha, \beta\colon f\to gα,β:f→g) is a 3-simplex Γ\GammaΓ such that

  • d0Γ=ididBd_0\Gamma = \mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{id}_B}d0​Γ=ididB​​,
  • d1Γ=idgd_1\Gamma = \mathrm{id}_gd1​Γ=idg​,
  • d2Γ=βd_2\Gamma = \betad2​Γ=β,
  • d3Γ=αd_3\Gamma = \alphad3​Γ=α.

The identity 3-morphism idα\mathrm{id_\alpha}idα​ is defined to be s2αs_2\alphas2​α.

This suggests the following definition of 4-morphism:

A 4-morphism from Γ\GammaΓ to Λ\LambdaΛ is a 4-simplex η\etaη such that

  • d0η=idididBd_0\eta=\mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{id}_B}}d0​η=idididB​​​,
  • d1η=ididgd_1\eta= \mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{id}_g}d1​η=ididg​​,
  • d2η=idβd_2\eta= \mathrm{id}_\betad2​η=idβ​,
  • d3η=Λd_3\eta= \Lambdad3​η=Λ,
  • d4η=Γd_4\eta= \Gammad4​η=Γ.

Then it makes sense to define the identity 4-morphism idΓ\mathrm{id}_\GammaidΓ​ as s3Γs_3\Gammas3​Γ.

Is that correct?

Is that the right pattern to inductively define "nnn-morphism fff between (n−1)(n-1)(n−1)-morphisms AAA, BBB":

  • dnf=Ad_nf=Adn​f=A,
  • dn−1f=Bd_{n-1}f=Bdn−1​f=B,
  • dn−2f=idcod(B)d_{n-2}f=\mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{cod}(B)}dn−2​f=idcod(B)​,
  • …\dots…,
  • d0f=id…idcod(…(cod(B)))d_0f=\mathrm{id}_{\dots_{\mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{cod}(\dots(\mathrm{cod}(B)))}}}d0​f=id…idcod(…(cod(B)))​​​?

Then it makes sense to define the identity nnn-morphism idA\mathrm{id}_AidA​ as sn−1As_{n-1}Asn−1​A.
How to define composition of nnn-morphisms? When is an nnn-morphism reversible? When is an nnn-morphism trivial? (If it is equivalent to an identity nnn-morphism? But what does "equivalent" mean?)
This is an interesting line of investigation, but alas, I don't have the energy for it myself - I'm busy with other projects. I hope someone else will enjoy working on this.

Here's an idea how to define composition of 2-morphisms α ⁣:f→g\alpha\colon f\to gα:f→g and β ⁣:g→h\beta\colon g\to hβ:g→h: say that γ ⁣:f→h\gamma\colon f\to hγ:f→h is a composition of α\alphaα and β\betaβ if there is a 3-simplex σ\sigmaσ with d1σ=βd_1\sigma=\betad1​σ=β, d2σ=γd_2\sigma=\gammad2​σ=γ, and d3σ=αd_3\sigma=\alphad3​σ=α.

Probably the notion of a morphism space or mapping space provides an answer to my questions. However, I haven't encountered them until now, because they are discussed beginning on page 667 in Kerodon.
